This all makes sense. No matter lockdowns, recession, filming oneself etc... It has nothing to do with any of this.

author: @LittlePhizDorrit
text: The tech companies offered these perks because employees were meant to be working 24/7.  In the early days of Silicon Valley you would hear of people sleeping under their desks, only eating fast food, working 100 hour weeks to get work done, etc.  These campuses were not designed to make work fun, but keep people working and not complaining.  They did the cost benefit analysis and decided that catered lunches and sleep pods were way cheaper than hiring more people or extending deadlines.

replies.author: @amorelus
replies.text:
I worked in a Tech Start up. They had foosball table, table tennis, snacks. TV.  It's not designed for people to slack off.  It's to help mental burn out dealing with hard to deal with projects. 

But like you stated. it's designed to keep people working longer, but also for mental release because clients can be hard to deal with and the deadlines can be unrealistic.  

I get more work done if I get 20 minutes to relax at work.  When I don't have this. It takes me all day to work one one task but if I can have a mental cool down. I can do alot more task.

This company I worked at only encourage you use the game room if you are productive and feel burnt out and or for team bonding.  It's not intended for you to waste time and slack off.

Anyone who is struggling and uses the game room. Almost all that I observed were let go.  Managers notices.

replies.author: @asw654
replies.text:
I work in Big Tech.

There's huge risk in telling employees that they've been laid off and/or especially when they're fired. 

When it's a layoff, what often happens is that they'll tell you, and then lock many of your internal accounts to minimize the possibility that you do damage to the company out of petty revenge (e.g. deleting or screwing with valuable documentation, data, etc). 

They'll still keep you around for a couple months or so, mainly to fulfill contractual obligations or to be nice and give you time to find a new job. It's basically your 60 day notice or whatever. But you're basically paid to do nothing (because we don't trust you to do honest work anymore) with minimal access anyway. A lot of people will feel traumatized like that employee because it's very sudden for you to suddenly lose access to many accounts (even ones you use for internal communication, so you lose many contacts, suddenly).

If it's a firing (for legit reasons), it's usually more severe because they don't need to warn you at all. Suddenly you're called in, and told to hand in your equipment (laptop and company phone) with no time to prepare, because they don't want to give you time to write your goodbyes or be dramatic over group emails, destroy valuable info, etc.

People who aren't used to that and don't understand why these are policies will often feel shocked/traumatized like her and wish they were given a warning. I don't think it's entitlement, tbh, it's just lack of preparation, and the sudden realization that they have no time to even say goodbye.

replies.author: @asw654
replies.text:
@AzathothTheGreat Oof, that's awful.

Though actually pretty common sentiment in big tech tbh. (Not the two months without pay part, but the part about coworkers and others getting angry at you for leaving suddenly.)

replies.text: I also dont feel any pity. My answer is "learn to weld" the same way those smug fucks told us blue-collars to "learn to code" when complaining about, for example, a local plant closing because of BS environmental regulations. Was my first and only layoff. Since then I always have an ear on the ground with the office gang to bail in time. Found a job a month later but many, especially older, did not have such luck. 1/3rd of the workers of a nearby village lost their job, more in others like my home, in one day. Most were older and did not find new jobs. The store closed a year later due to lacking demand, as did the bar. And what did we hear from the responsible politician(s) which choose to attend a townhall event in her official car (taxpayer financed big BMW or something, very environmentally friendly of course.....). blah blah "need to focus on retraining initiatives. Those guys were the best welders and metalworkers I know, definitly better than me both at the time and probably today. I am thankfull to have been their apprentice. And it makes me angry to see them on early retirement. Luckily most have gardens/trees to supplement their diet because retirement is low when you miss 4-5 years of employment and inflation runs rampant.

replies.author: @stagalgiz1097
replies.text:
You and me both, and that is on a good day. Even worse, when I worked in the oilfield, I was lucky if I got to take breaks or go home when it was quitting time. I've worked 21 and 24 hour days and go home for 24 off only to have my boss call and scream at me for not working another 10 to 12 hour shift after 21 or 24 hours straight, where I had to inform said idiot of a boss, "absolutely I will come in, but I want you to know this conversation is being recorded so if I am injured due to exhaustion, fatigue or whatever, I'll be sending this shit to OSHA and the state department of labor as well as my attorney. You know in case I get hurt or killed because I just worked 24 hours straight and you want to add another 12 straight which is highly illegal, let alone immoral, but sure, on my way...." The response was silence, followed by, "enjoy your day off and get some rest. We'll see you tomorrow buddy." Was it shady of me to do? A little. Was it smart? Well considering that working 21 to 24 hours straight requires a minimum of 24 off for safety. I know, I was a supervisor at another oilfield company, where I had classes on the laws before I went to this other company for more pay. 

Meanwhile, these crybabies got to only do 2 minutes of work, got naps and made far more than I did as a journeyman pipe fitter who was working on his master's. They made more than me, and did around ten minutes of work while I was working 50-70 hours a week or more, for less money and expected to basically give up my family life, beat my body up, break my back, and work like a rented mule, only to be put out to pasture while these entitled brats worked 10 minutes a week?! And don't get me started on my current job. Sure one of my routes is 4 hours one way, but then I have to unload the product (up to 500 lbs per item), put it up and move to the next item. Oh and there are 60 to 80 of these heavy, large items each trip, that I also loaded into the trailer. The days I do that route are 14-16 hour days. I am up at 4:30 and on the road by 5:30! These brats probably didn't roll out of bed before noon.... On a work day!

author: @lillones
text: As someone who deals with technical recruiters, what they are is; charismatic person who knows less than nothing about tech outside key buzzwords. Despite their lack of knowledge, they act as gatekeepers who will reject or approve your ability to talk to hiring managers. In short, they "help" the technical teams slim down their list of prospects based purely on if they like the person or not.

replies.author: @RomanHistoryFan476AD
replies.text: Ah so a waste of money then and likely could be driving talent away.

replies.author: @lillones
replies.text:
@RomanHistoryFan476AD well, the idea is that they will bring a much smaller list of people to the hiring manager who is often busy working on other projects. The real issue is, because they have no experience, they will cut people based off what could be less relevant things like people skills or work history.

You also run into overinflated egos. Your recruiter could come up with some "genius level" question that will determine if you get a call back. Possibly they will steer the conversation near politics or social habits to determine if you could be a "good fit". You could be the best person for the job, but because you didnt laugh at a joke, or because you give off "bad vibes", you may not even show on their radar.

replies.author: @p.s.shnabel3409
replies.text:
Yes and no.

I'm generally not one to forgive, nor give second chances - been there, done that, got burned. 

However, there are several points we need to consider in this case.

1. Innocent until proven guilty. Unless we have a smoking gun (e.g. video, tweet, blog), we don't know if the people we see are the same ones promoting lock downs and mandates. Is it highly likely (considering they live in deep blue areas, working for deep blue companies)? Yes. But I still need the proof before I condemn. 

2. Do we really want to go after the pitiful mutts, while their kennel masters get away in the ensuing chaos? Personally, I want the people at the helm to be held responsible. Legally, morally and financially. I want them to be barred from ever holding positions of power again. 

3. We all make mistakes, and a very necessary part of a healthy society is the ability to work towards redemption. It is something the far left does not understand (or practice) and it's tearing them apart. And while I don't forgive on a personal level, I see the benefit of having mechanisms in place that allow for people to grow and change.

4. From a very cynical point of view: those laid off in such a callous way are now highly susceptible to anyone showing them compassion. Why not swell our numbers, convert these former antagonists into allies? After all, we now have an enemy in common.  At worst, they ignore us, at best we find new friends.

5. The future will bring more lay offs, many more. If we laugh now (no matter how much we think it's justified), you better believe they'll return that 100 fold in the future. These are people with the emotional maturity of toddlers, they will absolutely burn everything down out of spite; is this really the hill we want to die on? 

6. Something we need to remember: before anything else, we are all Americans. If we want to stay one nation, we have to stop the rift. The left isn't going to do that, we know that. So, it's up to us. Constant bickering will drive us every further apart, holding out our hands (to those willing to take them) will bring us together. Which one do we choose?

Obviously, this is my own subjective take. I'm not saying any of the above is an absolute truth - it is how I see things.

replies.text:
@lazydaisy2292 I apply this principle in my daily life and have found it useful. Less misunderstandings, less drama and less negative consequences.

Sure, "teaching someone a a lesson" is a lot more gratifying momentarily, but the downside of that is when I get it wrong, I'll just have taught another person to dislike and distrust me.

There's also the point that just because a principle is encoded in law does not mean courts are the only place they apply. We use our rights, as guaranteed by the constitution, daily and outside  legal contexts.

Obviously, I am not you. Maybe you don't live like that. That is none of my business. Doesn't change the fact, though, that generally people can and do observe the spirit of the rights of we have in their daily lives.

replies.author: @asw654
replies.text:
Engineers are valuable, but their work is often a long term, ongoing process. If you already know you won't be holding them for a long time, they can be let go almost immediately because there's no point keeping them longer. 

You can't expect to squeeze just a bit more work from them, because even if they finish by the deadlines, you need to keep them around longer in case there are bugs (found internally or often much later by customers) in their finished product. Then it's better for the original architects/engineers to help solve the problems for their products. If they're not there, their product automatically has lower value because of these potential problems. Point is, there are many reasons their work is a long term investment. So there's no point in keeping them longer than they have to stay, because anything they make past the point where you know you can't keep them for much longer has less value. Might as well give them less work or ask them to pass on documentation and train others. 

Most other jobs don't involve work that go the distance like that. You can afford to keep them around longer, squeezing a bit more work out of them before finally needing to let go.

replies.author: @gorkyd7912
replies.text:
‚Äã@chowderwhillis9448 The best job for programmers is to be like the main developer for a small but successful business. Like a full stack dev or something who builds apps or brings the pieces together. This comes with some job security because if you're the only guy who knows how the system you built works then it's a pain to replace you, even if you're not doing much every day except maintaining the system. That or run your own business providing some kind of service like web development for other small businesses.

As a programmer for a big tech companies that is already established you would be totally replaceable. Programmers are coming into something that was already built, the technology and backend code is generally open source and everyone knows it, you have no rapport with the company executives and probably never will so there's no trust factor, and they bring in new bunches of programmers constantly and work them to death for a couple years til they burn out while promoting a few standouts to management positions to keep things somewhat cohesive for the next group of expendables. Pays well, but everyone who works there just wants "Google" on their resume for when they get a real job or start their own business somewhere sustainable.

replies.author: @Richie3Jack
replies.text:
This isn't about poor performers.  It's about improving stock prices.  Been going on for decades and happens across industries.  Years ago I was laid off at a job, but not because I was a poor performer.  They had a new CEO and a new HR manager.  I was labeled as an employee for the marketing department, but in reality I did work as data scientist for almost every department in the company.  They left the employees to be layed-off to the Director of HR who didn't have a clue and since I had less experience than other key employees (still 6 years with the company) I was let go.

2 weeks afterward they begged me to come back (they ended up firing the HR manager for this and other bone headed moves).  I turned them down because I had found a new job that paid me much more.

My parents thought the company was really stupid, but I had to explain to them that while this was a blunder, I'd rather take the company that realized they made a mistake and had the brains to do a mea culpa and try to get me back versus other companies that laid me off, making the same mistake, but didn't want to admit to it and ask me to come back. 

It just goes to show you that often times it has nothing to do with performance, there are just higher ups that make a lot of really dumb decisions.

replies.author: @gaerekxenos
replies.text: @charlespancamo9771 I'm not too sure these were made to promote the tech giant. Tech, as far as I am aware, will only allow certain bits of information to be circled around due to data leak issues. Which means videos like these would have to be very controlled in content. It could totally be possible they were allowed, then had the creators sacked for liability issues for cost savings afterwards -- but I am going to give Google the benefit of the doubt that these were not recorded with permission, which is a HUGE no-no with that industry. Media is generally heavily controlled there that you aren't allowed to bring cameras in for many places, and I believe there are even checks media people have to go through to see certain things. So having these people who are posting to social media on their work-day, then having them immediately locked out of company accounts the day they are sacked, makes a lot of sense. They are security hazards, short and simple, and for all I know could have been in violation of certain contract agreements for working there

replies.text: So one day when I was an engineering major, at the beginning of the semester, a very attractive woman, well-dressed, hair-styled, etc., walked into the classroom and sat down (I think the class was second semester quantum physics or calc, I can't recall).  The rest of the class was all male, scruffy, worn jeans, etc.  Someone from the back of the class said in a loud voice "She is in the WRONG classroom".  A moment or two later, she turned to the guy sitting beside her and asked "Is this Marketing?".  After receiving a resounding "No", she stood up and left, her heels clicking down the hallway.  It reinforced the stereotype that most women are more into superficialities like appearance and in getting by on their looks than in applying their intelligence to anything more intellectually challenging than trying to figure out which pair of Manolo Blahink shoes to wear with their Louis Vuitton hand bag.  And the sad truth is, most stereotypes are well-grounded in reality.

replies.text:
Google has an acceptance rate below 2%. You need to be really and I mean REALLY good to get an offer for SWE positions. 

Salaries are based on supply and demand. During the tech market boom top tier software engineers were scarce compared to the industry demand and salaries were high.

Now heading towards a potential recession companies are scaling down, cutting costs and, dropping moonshot projects. So naturally there are layoffs and new offers will have lower salaries. 

It's just capitalism playing its part. They were being paid what they were worth based on the market at that time.

replies.author: @sykomos
replies.text:
Hi, programmer here who's been in the same boat before: look into certifications for the field you're trying to get access to.  A college degree is little more than a certificate of scholastic achievement - a recruiter isn't going to be impressed with it no matter how great it is.  It's just a stop-gap that most companies feel "rules out the riff raff" (whether it actually is or isn't is a debate for another time).

Go for certifications that prove your skills will actually make money for a business.

It doesn't matter how smart or skilled you are in what you know how to do.., What matters is whether or not you can provide value to a business.  Can you use those skills to make a business make product or make money...  This is why college, ultimately, doesn't matter.  Being useful to a business always supercedes how artistic, well-spoken, or smart you are.

Also - go to every school-sanctioned job fair, if you're not doing that already.  These job fairs already filter out the general public and give you a leg up over the competition by virtue of being a student there.  Increased odds.

replies.author: @Kraken9911
replies.text:
Do you have a PhD in mathematics or physics?  Those are the people they and finance are looking for.

Multivariable calculus is still undergraduate level otherwise known as calc 3.  It's definitely not easy for everyone but these top tier employers are looking for people who excel at the cutting edge.

A while back I remember talking a physics PhD professor who confessed that a lot of his doctorate colleagues from uni went to go work in finance.

replies.author: @sykomos
replies.text:
‚Äã@Kraken9911 If people still aren't getting jobs, then the only conclusion I can come to is that it sounds like such degrees are but one requirement to getting in to these top tier businesses, and not the only thing you need.  I'm sure having a PhD in mathematics or physics is extremely hard to get, but being proficient in academia is not the same thing as being proficient in providing value to a business.

Get certified in skills they actually need and are asking for.  "Finance" is a big vague general term for a business field, just as "Information Technology" is... they encompass a lot.  I'd start thinking about using that intricate knowledge of numbers and seeing how any of that applies to what the financial sector actually needs specific to individual job titles... what are some common positions in the "finance" field (for IT, common fields are web developer, back-end developer, devsecops engineer, network security engineer... for finance, I'd imagine data analyst/scientist would be one such position to look for).  And what types of certs/experience would a company be looking for from a person trying to fill that position?  You might be able to participate in open-source projects or "jam nights" where you have at least some semblance of a product to show by the end.  

Companies want you to not only be smart, but be accomplished.  If you're not getting jobs, it's because your degree isn't enough, and they need you to show them a portfolio saying "here's how I've APPLIED my knowledge" (translation: here's my experience in actually providing you worth and value)

replies.author: @Richard_Potato
replies.text:

Six Sigma was mainly about data analysis, so it wasn't exactly a math class, but I could see the same (or similar) techniques having applications in finance.

replies.author: @p.s.shnabel3409
replies.text:
@SchnuckySchuster Think about it from HR's perspective: why should they change the way they are doing things?

There's (nearly always) more applicants than jobs. For middle of the road positions, they can pick and choose from many, many extremely well qualified job seekers.

So, what if the ones they tend to pick are the ones who also have the best social skills? Win/win for the company.

Admittedly, for those rare job openings where they need highly specialized (and sought after) masters of their field, the game changes. Companies will bend over backwards to get someone like that to work for them. 

But how many of us will ever be in that position? I have decades of experience in my field, I am really, really good at what I do ... and I still have to appease the gods of HR and not the other way around (because there are millions just like me).

In a perfect world, we'd all be nice to each other by default and be mindful of differences, limitations and preferences. 

... We've not been able to get anywhere close to that ideal in over a million years of evolution...

I'm not holding my breath to see it happening in my life time. Instead, I deal with reality as is. My energy is much better spent changing that which I can.

(On a side note, being involved with the hiring process seems to tickle out the crazy in some; I've seen people who really should know better turn into uptight bean-counters with a god complex; power is one hell of a drug, even in the smallest amounts)

replies.author: @asw654
replies.text:
I don't like a lot of these designs. They end up creating social bubbles almost as bad as college.

Look at the Facebook campus. I could literally go and get my hair cut there. Dentist. I could eat full course meal including some pretty good brisket and steak. If I didn't like that, I could instead go to the vegetarian corner, or the burger area, or just get gourmet ice cream.  Employees were often bringing their friends and families to work to eat free lunch with them. Lunch that would have normally cost them 40+ USD for each person, outside of their campus. Then they also buy up property so their employees can live closer to work. 

With arrangements like that, it's actually hard to leave Facebook. Turnover rate lowered, employee retention raised. People would need to find new barbers, dentists, favorite restaurants, good gyms, pay for new apartment, find new monthly parking, etc if they ever decided to leave. They're also stuck through more of the day around coworkers. 

It's like a mini community where people don't get insights/conversations with people outside a company. I wouldn't go to my own neighbourhood's gym, away from my company, I just go to my company's superior gym. Very easy to develop and foster social bubbles in such envs.

The utter obsession with "diversity, inclusion and equity" at the place I worked was in everything, and every single major meeting discussed it.
Meetings about recruitment discussed how they targeted their recruitment marketing material towards these "minority" groups.

replies.author: @andrewTaylorCodes
replies.text: Generally, engineers job hop for large compensation increases and chances to work on different tech. Often they will wait until any options vest. Some companies like Amazon are known to have cut throat engineering teams where they fire the lowest ~10% of performers each year.

replies.author: @darkdudironaji
replies.text: @andrewTaylorCodes I only know a few SWEs in FAANG personally, but none of them ever wait for their options to vest. Because it's really not worth it mathematically.
